text_description: Numbers of viral proteins: 100 S proteins, 20 E pentamers (100 proteins), 1000 M dimers (2000 proteins), 1000 N proteins
ref: Yinon M Bar-On, Avi Flamholz, Rob Phillips, Ron Milo. Science Forum: SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) by the numbers. eLife 2020;9:e57309 DOI: 10.7554/eLife.57309

text_description: S protein model: PDB 6VSB; M protein dimer and E protein pentamers were downloaded from Feig lab repository
Cell surface proteins: ACE2 model: PDB 6M17 (purple); TMPRSS2 (orange) and furin (yellow): no PDB available for the transmembrane domains

30kb RNA should be around 8000 nm long. There is still uncertainty regarding how much RNA is tightly bound by N proteins. This model is based on the observations by Klein & al that the genome is packaged around multiple separate RNP complexes
ref:
Klein S, Cortese M, Winter SL, Wachsmuth-Melm
M, Neufeldt CJ, Cerikan B, Stanifer ML, Boulant S,
Bartenschlager R, Chlanda P. SARS-CoV-2 
structure and replication characterized by in situ 
cryo-electron tomography. Nat Commun. 2020 Nov 
18;11(1):5885. doi: 10.1038/s41467-020-19619-7.

text_description: N protein CTD (PDB: 6YI3) and NTD (PDB: 6YUN) models were arranged in octamers as described in Chen et al 2007 for SARS-CoV1. Uncertainty about the exact structure of the RNPs
ref:
Chun-Yuan Chen, Chung-ke Chang, 
Yi-Wei Chang, Shih-Che Sue, Hsin-I Bai, 
Lilianty Riang, Chwan-Deng Hsiao, and 
Tai-huang Huang. Structure of the SARS 
Coronavirus Nucleocapsid Protein 
RNA-binding Dimerization Domain Suggests
 a Mechanism for Helical Packaging of Viral 
RNA. J Mol Biol. 2007 May 11; 
368(4): 1075–1086.

text_description:
Translation is intiated by a Cap-dependent
mechanism and cellular ribosomes start synthetizing the viral polyproteins
ref:
Viral and Cellular mRNA Translation in Coronavirus-Infected 
Cells. Nakagawa K, Lokugamage KG, Makino S. Adv Virus Res. 
2016; 96():165-192.

text_description: Translation Initiation Complex
Ribosome model is from PDB 5AJ0

Nucleocapsid disassembly. Significant uncertainty 
about the precise mechanism
Nsp1 is from PDB 2HSX
Nsp2 model was downloaded from Zhang lab repository

Nsp3 model is created from a series of disctinct
 structures: UB1 domain is from PDB 2IDY;
ADPR domain is from PDB 2ACF; SUD-N-M is from 
PDB 2W2G; SUD-C is from PDB 2KAF; UB2-PL2Pro
is from PDB 2FE8; NAB is from PDB 2K87; the 
unsolved regions were modeled from the predicted
structure downloaded from Zhang lab repository. 
The relative organization of the domains is 
uncertain but supposedly flexible

text_description:
Polyprotein cleavage by Nsp3 protease domain 
probably starts early during translation and prior to 
membrane insertion. The protease domain is sufficient for 
processing the predicted nsp1/2 and nsp2/3 sites, but the 
downstream hydrophobic domain is required for 
processing at the predicted nsp3/4 site
We expect that at least some of the cleavages need to 
occur in cis early in infection when the protein concentration
is low.
ref:
Harcourt B.H., Jukneliene D., Kanjanahaluethai A., Bechill J.,
 Severson K.M., Smith C.M., Rota P.A., Baker S.C. 
Identification of severe acute respiratory syndrome 
coronavirus replicase products and characterization of 
papain-like protease activity. Journal of Virology. 
2004;78(24):13600–13612.

text_description:
Nsp4 model was downloaded from Zhang lab 
repository and the domains were rotated and moved 
relative to one another to fit inside the membrane. 
This assumes the presence of flexible linker regions

Nsp4 model was downloaded from Zhang lab 
repository and the domains were rotated and moved 
relative to one another to fit inside the membrane. 
This assumes the presence of flexible linker regions
Nsp5 is from PDB 6Y2E
Nsp6 model was downloaded from Zhang lab repository

The mechanism of nsp3, 4 and 6 into the ER 
membrane is purely speculative; it is depicted here
as being co-translationnal and involving Sec61
Sec61 model is from PDB 3J7Q
Nsp7 model is from PDB 6YYT
Nsp8 model is from PDB 6YYT

Polyprotein processing by the main protease (Nsp5) 
is thought to happen in a co-translational manner.
Most of the cleavages are mediated in trans by the fully 
processed and dimeric form of Nsp5, even if at least some 
cleavages probably need to occur in cis early in infection
Nsp9 model is from PDB 6WXD
Nsp10 model is from PDB 6W75
Nsp11 structure is not solved; it is so small (13AA) that it has been omitted here

The -1 ribosomal frameshifting signals are composed of a 
slippery sequence “UUUAAAC” followed by a “stimulatory” 
RNA secondary structure.
The pseudoknot structure is from PDB 6XRZ
ref:
Baranov P.V., Henderson C.M., Anderson C.B., Gesteland 
R.F., Atkins J.F., Howard M.T. Programmed ribosomal 
frameshifting in decoding the SARS-CoV genome. 
Virology. 2005;332:498–510.

text_description:
Frameshifting is depicted as 
described in the preprint from Bhatt & al.
ref:
Structural basis of ribosomal frameshifting during 
translation of the SARS-CoV-2 RNA genome
Pramod R. Bhatt, Alain Scaiola, Gary Loughran, Marc 
Leibundgut, Annika Kratzel, Angus McMillan, Kate M. 
O’ Connor, Jeffrey W. Bode, Volker Thiel, John F. Atkins, 
Nenad Ban
bioRxiv 2020.10.26.355099; 
doi: https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.10.26.355099

text_description:
Processing of the nsp7-10 polyprotein segment by the 
main protease has been shown by Kriechel & al to 
happen in the following order: nsp10, then nsp9 and 
then nsp8 from nsp7
ref:
Krichel B., Falke S., Hilgenfeld R., Redecke L. and 
Uetrecht C. (2020) Processing of the SARS-CoV pp1a/ab 
nsp7-10 region. Biochem. J. 477, 1009–1019 
10.1042/BCJ20200029

text_description: Nsp12 model is from PDB 6YYT
Nsp13 model is from PDB 6JYT
Nsp14 model is from PDB 5NFY
Nsp15 model is from PDB 6W01
Nsp16 model is from PDB 6W75

The processing order of nsp12-16 polyprotein segment 
by the main protease is unknown.

Nsp3 and nsp4 luminal domains interact to induce membrane
pairing; the exact nature of these interactions (nsp3-nsp3,
nsp4-nsp4, nsp3-nsp4?) is still unclear.
ref:
Hagemeijer M.C., Monastyrska I., Griffith J., van der Sluijs P., 
Voortman J., van Bergen en Henegouwen P.M. Membrane 
rearrangements mediated by coronavirus nonstructural 
proteins 3 and 4. Virology. 2014;458–459:125–135.

text_description:
The mechanisms of membrane curvature and double 
membrane vesicle formation depicted here are still 
speculative.
In addition to nsp3 and nsp4, nsp6 is also involved.
Some host factors might also participate.
ref:
Oudshoorn D, Rijs K, Limpens RWAL, Groen K, Koster AJ, 
Snijder EJ, Kikkert M, Bárcena M. Expression and Cleavage 
of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus nsp3-4 
Polyprotein Induce the Formation of Double-Membrane 
Vesicles That Mimic Those Associated with Coronaviral 
RNA Replication. mBio. 2017 Nov 21;8(6):e01658-17. 
doi: 10.1128/mBio.01658-17. 

Wolff, G., Melia, C. E., Snijder, E. J., & Bárcena, M. 
(2020). Double-Membrane Vesicles as Platforms for Viral 
Replication. Trends in microbiology, 28(12), 1022–1033. 
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tim.2020.05.009

text_description:
The double membrane vesicles range between 150-300nm 
in diameter and contain RNA filaments
The distance between paired membranes has been 
measured to be approximately 4.5nm.
ref:
Klein, S., Cortese, M., Winter, S. L., Wachsmuth-Melm, 
M., Neufeldt, C. J., Cerikan, B., Stanifer, M. L., Boulant, 
S., Bartenschlager, R., & Chlanda, P. (2020). 
SARS-CoV-2 structure and replication characterized by 
in situ cryo-electron tomography. Nature communications, 
11(1), 5885. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-020-19619-7

Wolff, G., Limpens, R., Zevenhoven-Dobbe, J. C., 
Laugks, U., Zheng, S., de Jong, A., Koning, R. I., Agard, D. A., 
Grünewald, K., Koster, A. J., Snijder, E. J., & Bárcena, M. 
(2020). A molecular pore spans the double membrane of 
the coronavirus replication organelle. Science 
 369(6509), 1395–1398. https://doi.org/10.1126/science.abd3629
